title: 115_hr5124
content: The Act titled "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" establishes the Community Action Opioid Response Grant Program. The "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" establishes a grant program through the Office of Community Services to help Community Action Agencies address the opioid addiction epidemic among low-income individuals and communities. Eligible agencies can apply for grants to support efforts in identifying and responding to opioid misuse and addiction. Grant funds can be used for various activities to combat the crisis. The "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" establishes a grant program through the Office of Community Services to help Community Action Agencies address opioid addiction among low-income individuals and communities. Grant funds can be used for activities such as public education, outreach, direct services, stabilizing needs, addressing impact on children, and developing partnerships. The "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" establishes a grant program for Community Action Agencies to address opioid addiction. Grants can be used for activities like developing partnerships with various entities, training agency personnel, and have funding limitations of $50,000 to $1,000,000 per year for up to three years. The Community Action Agency receiving a grant must submit an annual report detailing goals, interventions, outcomes, and expenditures. The Secretary will make these reports public on the Department of Health and Human Services website and compile them for Congress with an annual summary. The Secretary will establish an expedited grant application, review, and award process within 60 days of the enactment of the section. The criteria for grants will be published in the Federal Register and require specific information in the application. The grant application must include a description of program objectives, innovative approaches, a plan for measuring progress, identification of partner organizations, and assurances to the Secretary. The grant application must include assurances that the applicant has assessed community needs related to opioid misuse among low-income individuals, will not supplant other programs, and will use evidence-based approaches. The Secretary will establish a Community Action Opioid Response Grant Application Review Panel within 90 days of the enactment of this section. The Grant Application Review Panel, consisting of at least 15 individuals with expertise in various areas related to the opioid epidemic, will review and evaluate grant applications. Priority will be given to applications demonstrating coordination with agencies experienced in addressing opioid-related issues. The Grant Application Review Panel, comprised of experts in the opioid epidemic, will prioritize applications showing coordination with agencies experienced in addressing opioid-related issues. Evaluation criteria include leveraging non-Federal funds, quality of methodology, capacity-building, minimizing trauma of foster care on children of addicted individuals, and knowledge of opioid-related needs in the target community. The Secretary may use appropriated funds for the Community Action Opioid Response Grant Application Review Panel. Grants must be awarded within 120 days of funds availability. $50,000,000 is authorized for grants each fiscal year. The Secretary may use $50,000,000 for grants each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022. Not more than 7 percent of the funds can be designated for grants to Indian tribes or tribal organizations. Definitions include the Secretary as the Secretary of Health and Human Services and Community Action Agency as an eligible entity under the Community Services Block Grant Act.
